title: ‘Landslide’: Santana beats out Baker, Wu says, while Culpepper wins D7
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Rev. Miniard Culpepper wins Boston City Council District 7 seat, defeating Said Ahmed by 500 votes.
Henry Santana secures reelection as at-large City Councilor, beating former Councilor Frank Baker, according to Mayor Wu.
All Boston City Council incumbents, including Districts 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, and 9, won their races against challengers.

title: Jake Wilson to be Somerville’s next mayor, unofficial results show
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: City Councilor Jake Wilson will be the next mayor of Somerville, receiving 11,185 votes in unofficial results.
Opponent Willie Burnley Jr. conceded, after receiving 9,054 votes; Wilson's campaign focused on improving city services.
Wilson plans to address issues like housing, street safety, and rodent problems, with a regional approach to solutions.

title: Lowell police seeking public’s help with details about fatal hit-and-run
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Lowell police are seeking public assistance regarding a fatal hit-and-run on Chelmsford Street on October 30.
A woman was fatally struck by a vehicle just before midnight; the driver fled the scene after the incident.
Police have located the vehicle involved but need more details; they ask anyone with information to call 978-937-3200.

title: ‘This is just the beginning’: Nonbinding Israel divestment ballot question passes in Somerville
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: Somerville voters passed a nonbinding ballot measure to divest from companies supporting Israel's actions in Palestine, with 55.7% approval.
The grassroots initiative, led by Somerville for Palestine, gathered over 11,000 signatures and faced legal challenges from opposition groups.
Opponents, including Somerville United Against Discrimination, argue the measure creates community division without addressing local issues.

title: Tom Brady just revealed that his dog Junie is a clone of Lua, his deceased furry friend
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Tom Brady cloned his deceased dog Lua, resulting in new dog Junie, using Colossal Biosciences' technology.
Lua, a brown Pitbull mix, was cloned prior to her death in December 2023 by the biotech firm Colossal.
Colossal Biosciences, where Brady is an investor, recently acquired leading cloning company Viagen for species conservation.

title: Running unopposed, Michelle Wu secures second term as her national profile grows
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Michelle Wu secures second term as Boston mayor, running unopposed in November's election.
Wu's national profile rises after testifying to Congress against Trump administration's immigration claims.
Wu maintains 66% favorability and received over 30,000 votes with 91.10% support in reported results.

title: Tell us: What should Mayor Wu focus on in her second term?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu is expected to serve a second term unopposed in Boston's general election.
Wu has focused on housing affordability, immigration tensions, and climate goals during her first term as mayor.
Residents are invited to submit suggestions for Wu's priorities in her upcoming term through a Boston.com form.

title: ‘This is kidnapping — plain and simple’: ICE arrests 9 employees at Allston car wash
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: ICE agents detained nine employees with work permits at Allston Car Wash on Cambridge Street.
The detentions occurred before employees could retrieve documents from lockers, leading to language barrier issues.
Boston City Councilor Liz Breadon condemned the raid, urging community assistance and reporting of ICE activities.

title: Patriots opt to stand pat at trade deadline
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Patriots opted not to make any trades at the NFL deadline, maintaining their 7-2 roster.
Despite their six-game winning streak, the Patriots traded away Keion White and Kyle Dugger for depth reasons.
The team could face challenges in running back and defense due to injuries and lack of trade acquisitions.

title: Amid SNAP benefit cuts, these Greater Boston food businesses are here to help
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Greater Boston food businesses offer free meals, discounts, and donations to assist residents amid federal SNAP benefit cuts.
Local restaurants and grocery stores partner with nonprofits to set up community fridges and free food distribution programs.
SNAP benefits were at risk of freezing due to a government shutdown, prompting local aid efforts from Boston food businesses.
